726164f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, west from Vernon Boulevard, seen across the Long Island Railroad yards. The buildings are old tenements and are on the north side of the avenue, extending west to the East River. In the center, next to a pair of shacks, is the 4-story building of the Long JIsland Railroad branch of the Y.M.C.A. at the N.W. corner of Fifth Street. Across the latter is the Pennsylvania Railroad power house, at 51st Avenue and Second Street. The mid-Manhattan skyline, with the Chrysler building prominently visible, is in the background. View 2 shows the north side of the avenue. On the left is the Empire State Building. View 3 shows the south side of the avenue and the old Long Island City railroad station, on 2nd
Street.
P. L. Sperr  August 25, 1936
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 1,2,3
726164f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726164f-b.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726160f-b.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, east from Vernon Boulevard, showing the Thompson lumber yard. All structures along the avenue were later torn down and the plaza of the Queens Midtown Tunnel constructed here.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726160f-b.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726160f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, east from Vernon Boulevard, showing the Thompson lumber yard. All structures along the avenue were later torn down and the plaza of the Queens Midtown Tunnel constructed here.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority

726160f-c.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, east from Vernon Boulevard, showing the Thompson lumber yard. All structures along the avenue were later torn down and the plaza of the Queens Midtown Tunnel constructed here.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726160f-c.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726159f-a.text:
10-17 Borden Avenue, north side, just east of Vernon Boulevard. This building,among others, was razed to make way for the construction of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel plaza. To its
right is the M.H. Thompson lumber yard.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726159f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726161f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, between Vernon Boulevard and 11th Street, showing the interior of M.H. Thompson's lumber yard. The view is eastward and shows the rears of houses fronting on the south side of 51st Avenue. The lumber yard and the dwellings were later obliterated and the Queens Midtown Tunnel plaza was erected here. The view marks the direct line of the new road from where later will be the exit
from the tunnel.
November 21, 1938
New ork City Tunnel Authority
726161f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726162f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, south side, east from Vernon Boulevard, showing the Long Island Railroad yards in the immediate neighborhood of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726162f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726163f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, east from Vernon Boulevard. All structures, extending as far as the water tank in front of the white factory building, were later torn down and the area converted into the sunken plaza of the GCueens-Midtown Tunnel. Note the M.H. Thompson lumber yard in the center.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726163f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726942f-a.text:
Jackson Avenue, north side, at Vernon Boulevard, near the OQueens-Midtown Tunnel plama. The vehicular
viaduct is on Vernon Boulevard.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726942f-a.folder: Jackson Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726943f-a.text:
Jackson Avenue, south side, at Vernon Boulevard, showing the Clay Building and an adjoining 3 story house. These buildings were later razed and the site was made the point of entrance to the Queens Midtown Tunnel.
November 22, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726943f-a.folder: Jackson Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

728150f-a.folder: Vernon Boulevard & Borden Avenue, Queens, NY

728152f-a.text: Vernon Boulevard, east side, at Borden Avenue (vantage point). Shown is a general view eastward across the area lying between Borden Avenue (right) and 51st Avenue, which marks the direct line of the highway that will lead from the Queens-Midtown Tunnel exit. In the immediate foreground will be built the sunken plaza and the mouth of the tunnel.  As the highway will reach the small group of tenements (center) it will bend to the left and across the clearance between the factories; that portion of the road will be elevated. On the right are the Long Island Railroad yards and Newtown Creek, marking the boundary between Queens and Brooklyn.  November 19, 1938   New York Tunnel Authority
728152f-a.folder: Vernon Boulevard & Borden Avenue, Queens, NY

726156f-a.text:
10-11 Borden Avenue, adjoining the N.E. corner of Vernon Boulevard. This house, as well as all others on the block, were later torn down to make way for the construction of the sunken plaza of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. On the left is the rear of the Clay Building, on Jackson Avenue. This site, below
street level, marks the tunnel's exit.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726156f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

728151f-a.text:
Vernon Boulevard, east side, at Borden Avenue (vantage point). Shown in a general view in a northeasterly direction across part of which was later constructed the Queens-Midtown Tunnel highway after numerous buildings were razed. The area from the foreground extending to the right as far as the group of low tenements -- this being the south side of 51st Avenue--was later converted into the plaza of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, after all the buildings were torn down. On the left is Jackson Avenue.

November 19, 1938

New York City Tunnel Authority
728151f-a.folder: Vernon Boulevard & Borden Avenue, Queens, NY

728155f-b.text:
Vernon Boulevard, north from Jackson Avenue, which is on the right. This is the ramp over the Long Island Railroad yards and leads to Brooklyn, in the opposite direction, over, Newtown Creek. In the background is St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, at 49th Avenue, and the Queensboro Bridge.

P. L. Sperr                             View 1: October 23, 1930
NO REPRODUCTIONS                        View 2: October 25, 1936
